Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Dissertation Award: Status Related Resource Distribution

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: The Spanish colonization of the Americas had profound impacts on indigenous societies, but archaeological research has documented both change and continuity in economic, social, and political structures during the 16th and 17th centuries, implying a diversity of interactions and responses. This project uses zooarchaeology, the study of archaeological animal remains, to evaluate the impact of Spanish colonialism on households. Building on previous site-level investigations, this study considers continuities and transformations in the access to animal resources by specific community members as they adapted to the new Colonial order. Zooarchaeology is well placed to study periods of culture contact because animals can serve not only as basic resources, but also as indicators of cultural identity, luxury items, and symbols of status and power display. Thus, their material remains in the archaeological record provide a proxy of the past economic, social, and political systems in which they were used. In this study, the application of innovative zooarchaeological techniques provides a refined view of animal use by householders of different social status and political authority through the period of Spanish contact. In turn, this offers insight into the role played by status and political standing in how people react and adapt to times of instability. The project also incorporates methodological advancements by (1) presenting a new method combining taphonomy (the study of post-depositional histories of archaeological remains), skeletal element refitting, and radiocarbon dating to resolve issues of poor stratigraphic and chronological resolution; and (2) using a multi-isotope approach to investigate animal trade and management practices from pre-Columbian to Colonial times. Through museum exhibits and academic and public talks this project will generate discussions on the retention and loss of indigenous political economy in marginal areas. This research project will also train undergraduate students in methods of identification and analysis of zooarchaeological remains through hands-on lab activities. <br/><br/>To document change or persistence in cultural practices in marginal communities under Spanish rule, zooarchaeological remains are studied in two steps. First, taphonomic, refitting, and radiocarbon data are used to refine the chronology of deposits from seven households. Second, differences in the access to and control over animal resources and related activities are identified by comparing taxonomic, skeletal, and isotopic data among contexts (elite vs. non-elite, ruler vs. ruled) and periods (pre-Columbian vs. Colonial). Together, these lines of evidence will allow one to determine (1) if the elite maintained their status and power by retaining access to valued animal resources; and (2) if non-elite community members developed new strategies of animal exploitation to adapt to the Colonial order. Overall, these analyses will document relations of production and distribution of animal resources in Spanish borderlands and assess the impact of Spanish colonialism on the pursuit of these activities.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF-funded project Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant "Identifying Household-level Political Economy on the Maya/Spanish Frontier through Zooarchaeology" (NSF-BCS DDRI #2001676, PI Emery, co-PI Boileau) used zooarchaeology to examine changes and continuities in household activities of the ancient Maya living in the archaeological community of Lamanai, Belize, located in the "border zone" at the edge of colonization activities during the time immediately before and after Spanish contact (AD 1450-1700). Zooarchaeology is the study of animal remains recovered from archaeological sites and provides information on subsistence, economics, politics, and religion through the lens of animal-human interactions. Our project documented persistence in Maya animal-related cultural practices carried out by community members of different social standing, such as rulers, elite individuals, and commoners, on the Maya/Spanish frontier. Importantly, our research showed that the ancient Maya successfully negotiated the dramatic social and political transformations taking place in the colonial sphere, an example of Indigenous resilience to colonialism. 

With funding from the National Science Foundation, we analyzed nearly 10,000 animal remains. These animal bones were recovered from seven Lamanai residences, one the home of the ruling elite, two of non-ruling elite, and four of non-elite community members. The first goal of our research was to determine if the archaeological deposits in which the animal bones were found dated to the pre-Columbian or colonial periods. We developed a new method combining taphonomy (the study of post-depositional histories of archaeological remains), skeletal element refitting, and radiocarbon dating. We found that the bone accumulations corresponded to different activities taking place at the site over time, as opposed to being single mixed deposits. The data allowed us to show that most of the households were occupied during the colonial period, with a few deposits accumulating before Spanish contact. This method provides an important new technique that could be used at other sites with poor stratigraphic or chronological resolution. 

Our second goal was to determine if animal use changed from the pre-Columbian to colonial periods. We found that the Maya of Lamanai mostly continued to use animals in the same way over time. During the colonial period, they hunted animals like deer and armadillos that lived in agricultural fields and gardens. They also caught turtles and fish in rivers using nets and traps. We also found that the Maya continued to raise turkeys during the colonial period and, unlike in other neighboring regions, did not use new animals introduced by Europeans, like cows, chickens, or pigs. In addition, they continued to participate in Indigenous exchange networks outside Spanish control. Animals from the Caribbean coast, such as stingrays, sea turtles, and marine shells, were still available at colonial-period Lamanai, indicating continuity of trade in elite exotic resources. Using multi-isotope geochemistry, we found evidence for one non-local deer, which also suggests continued trade of dietary and economic staples between Lamanai and other Indigenous groups during this time. This is surprising because previous research suggested that Spanish colonial rule disrupted traditional trade networks. Our results show that the Maya of Lamanai worked to keep their own traditions and ways of life instead of adopting European ways. This persistence in Indigenous animal use is critical at a time when the Spanish colonial regime and missionization efforts threatened the "Maya" identity.

Finally, we also investigated the role of social standing in navigating the colonial-period transformations. We found that animal use was one of the ways in which differences between and within socio-political groups were expressed at Lamanai after Spanish contact. As in pre-colonial periods, higher social and political positioning continued to be defined by access to a greater diversity of animal types, a more significant number of animals from habitats other than rivers, the best meat cuts from river turtles and freshwater fishes, and higher quantities of crafted marine and bone shell objects. Based on these differences, we proposed that the post-contact Lamanai community was divided into five hierarchical classes: a ruling elite, a non-ruling elite, and a higher-status, middle-status, and lower-status non-elite. Furthermore, our work showed that non-elite community members likely acted as hunters, fishmongers, and butchers that acquired and prepared animals for elite consumption, indicating continuity of socio-economic and political relationships between status groups. This work is the first to identify differences in within- and between-group access to animal resources in a contact-period Maya community. As such, it highlights the diversity of social, political, and occupational roles in ancient Maya communities, differences that persisted even under Spanish rule.
